title: 109_hr3003
content: Established in the legislative branch, the Independent Commission on the Investigation of Detainee Abuses (referred to as the "Commission") is tasked with investigating detainee abuses. The Commission will investigate abuses of detainees in operations related to the Global War on Terrorism, including the extent of the abuses, reasons for their occurrence, responsible parties, and failures in policies and procedures that led to the abuses. Recommendations for legislative and executive actions to prevent future abuses will also be made. The Commission will assess the influence of Guantanamo Detention Center policies on other detention centers, evaluate relevant persons and agencies involved in the approval process for interrogation techniques, and make recommendations to prevent future abuses. The Commission will investigate the integration of military police and intelligence operations in detainee interrogation, the involvement of civilian contractors in abuses, warnings from NGOs, Congress's awareness of the abuses, and the US compliance with the Geneva Conventions. The investigation will also look into whether the United States violated international law by restricting access to detainees by the International Committee of the Red Cross and compliance with human rights treaties. SEC. 3. COMPOSITION OF COMMISSION. The Commission shall consist of 10 members appointed by various leaders, with specific qualifications for non-government appointees. The Commission will consist of 10 members appointed based on specific qualifications, including prominent US citizens with expertise in various fields. Members must be appointed within 45 days of the Act's enactment, with the chairman and vice chairman elected by a majority vote. The Commission will commence operations promptly after formation. The Commission, consisting of 10 members with specific qualifications, will meet upon the call of the chairman or majority. Six members constitute a quorum, vacancies do not affect powers but are filled as per original appointment. Members must submit financial disclosure reports and be independent from subjects of investigations. The Commission, consisting of 10 members with specific qualifications, will meet upon the call of the chairman or majority. Six members constitute a quorum, vacancies do not affect powers but are filled as per original appointment. Members must submit financial disclosure reports and be independent from subjects of investigations. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 4. The Commission, consisting of 10 members with specific qualifications, has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, and issue subpoenas to gather evidence for carrying out its duties outlined in Section 4. The Commission, consisting of 10 members with specific qualifications, has the authority to issue subpoenas for gathering evidence. Subpoenas can be issued by the agreement of the chairman and vice chairman or by the affirmative vote of 6 members. Subpoenas may be served by any person designated by the chairman or a majority of the Commission. Enforcement measures are in place for cases of contumacy. In cases of contumacy or failure to obey a subpoena, the United States district court can issue an order for the person to testify or produce evidence. Failure to comply may result in contempt of court. Additional enforcement measures are in place for witnesses who fail to comply. The Commission has the authority to certify witness failures to comply with subpoenas to the United States attorney for possible grand jury action. The Commission can examine actions and representations under its duties. The Commission has the authority to examine actions and representations of the current and prior Administrations. It can enter into contracts and obtain information from federal agencies to fulfill its duties under this Act. The Commission can request information from federal agencies and receive administrative support from the General Services Administration for its functions. Information handling must comply with relevant laws and regulations. The Commission may receive assistance, services, funds, and support from US departments and agencies as authorized by law. It can also accept gifts, use postal services like other government entities. SEC. 5. NONAPPLICABILITY OF FEDERAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE ACT. The Commission is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. It will hold public meetings, release public reports, and conduct hearings while protecting sensitive information. SEC. 6. STAFF OF COMMISSION. The Commission can appoint staff without following typical federal hiring rules, with a limit on pay. Staff are considered federal employees. The Commission can appoint staff without following typical federal hiring rules, with a limit on pay. Staff are considered federal employees under section 2105 of title 5, United States Code. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement and retain their rights, status, and privileges. The Commission is authorized to procure consultant services. The Commission can appoint staff without typical federal hiring rules, with pay not exceeding level IV of the Executive Schedule. They are considered federal employees and can procure consultant services. SEC. 7. Compensation and Travel Expenses: Commission members may receive compensation at a daily rate equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule. They are also entitled to travel expenses while performing Commission duties. SEC. 8. Security Clearances for Commission Members and Staff. SEC. 8. Security clearances for Commission members and staff are provided by appropriate Federal agencies or departments, subject to existing procedures and requirements. Access to classified information requires the necessary security clearance. The Commission can submit interim and final reports to Congress and the President with findings, conclusions, and recommendations. Reports must be unclassified but may include a classified annex. If deemed in the public interest, certain classified information may be made available to the public. The Commission can submit reports to Congress and the President with recommendations. If deemed in the public interest, classified information may be made public. Procedures for declassifying information involve recommendations to congressional intelligence committees. The term "congressional intelligence committees" refers to the Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence of the House of Representatives and the Select Committee on Intelligence of the Senate. SEC. 10. TERMINATION. The Commission and its authorities will end 60 days after submitting the final report. The Commission can use this period to wrap up activities and present reports to Congress. SEC. 11. FUNDING. Up to $5,000,000 is authorized for the Commission's activities, with funds available until the Commission's termination.
